section: predict.py examples/lichtman/predict.py Go to the documentation of this file.00001 00002 ''' 00003 This example is based on election prediction data from 00004 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Keys_to_the_White_House 00005 00006 The prediction model was developed by Allan Lichtman and Russian geophysicist Vladimir Keilis-Borok 00007 and uses 13 key properties to predict the outcome of an election. 00008 00009 It can predict correctly almost all past presidential elections in the USA since 1860. 00010 00011 This example proves, that it cannot reliably predict the 2024 election. 00012 00013 Lichtmann assigns all his criteria the same weight (1.0) and defines a limit sum, 00014 which fits well with past elections. 00015 00016 If we could apply different weights and thresholds to Lichtman's criteria, 00017 it suggests that the model could yield alternative predictions, 00018 especially for elections where the context varies from those on which the model 00019 was originally calibrated. This means that while the "13 Keys" may fit historical data well, 00020 other configurations might fit just as well but lead to different forecasts. 00021 Essentially, Lichtman’s model may not be the only equally valid model; 00022 alternative configurations could yield differing, yet valid, predictions, 00023 implying potential flexibility in interpreting election outcomes. 00024 00025 To prove this statement we have to find weights for the 13 keys and corresponding limits, so that 00026 a) It is predicted that Harris wins 2024 00027 and other weights + limits, so that 00028 b) It is predicted that Trump wins 2024 00029 00030 Executing test_harris_prediciton() we get: 00031 00032 Harris looses 00033 00034 num correct 42.0 weights [1.684, 1.731, 1.968, 0.47, 2.326, 1.491, 0.104, 0.924, 0.93, 0.516, 0.213, 0.585, 0.057] limit 4.75 00035 num correct 42.0 weights [1.637, 1.552, 1.122, 0.015, 1.434, 0.329, 0.969, 0.697, 0.487, 1.711, 0.024, 1.709, 1.314] limit 5.458 00036 num correct 42.0 weights [1.457, 1.685, 0.888, 0.072, 1.996, 0.115, 0.576, 0.949, 0.95, 1.641, 0.292, 1.186, 1.191] limit 4.915 00037 num correct 42.0 weights [1.483, 1.538, 1.71, 0.039, 1.648, 0.204, 0.512, 0.629, 0.907, 1.21, 0.459, 1.466, 1.196] limit 5.261 00038 num correct 42.0 weights [1.709, 1.71, 1.507, 0.9, 1.072, 0.216, 0.924, 0.93, 1.092, 1.54, 0.258, 0.919, 0.224] limit 5.343 00039 num correct 42.0 weights [1.04, 1.247, 1.462, 0.667, 1.423, 0.357, 0.539, 0.992, 0.762, 1.444, 0.522, 1.203, 1.34] limit 5.122 00040 num correct 42.0 weights [1.636, 2.098, 1.194, 0.455, 1.312, 0.493, 0.383, 0.499, 0.802, 1.237, 0.136, 1.725, 1.031] limit 5.789 00041 num correct 42.0 weights [2.028, 0.921, 1.675, 0.644, 1.532, 0.313, 0.224, 0.36, 0.277, 1.382, 0.995, 1.474, 1.176] limit 5.871 00042 num correct 42.0 weights [2.746, 2.226, 1.448, 0.419, 0.801, 0.137, 1.11, 0.157, 1.799, 1.203, 0.663, 0.011, 0.28] limit 5.056 00043 num correct 42.0 weights [1.375, 1.496, 1.436, 0.252, 1.553, 0.555, 0.807, 0.558, 0.695, 1.817, 0.988, 0.489, 0.98] limit 4.561 00044 00045 Harris wins 00046 00047 num correct 42.0 weights [1.227, 0.999, 1.124, 1.446, 0.937, 0.89, 1.47, 1.059, 0.668, 1.089, 0.419, 0.712, 0.958] limit 5.597 00048 num correct 42.0 weights [1.449, 1.521, 1.416, 0.982, 1.456, 1.202, 0.119, 0.791, 0.847, 0.099, 0.695, 1.111, 1.312] limit 5.328 00049 num correct 42.0 weights [1.598, 0.878, 1.299, 1.021, 1.233, 0.883, 0.927, 1.146, 0.804, 0.956, 1.384, 0.137, 0.734] limit 5.603 00050 num correct 42.0 weights [0.202, 1.353, 0.649, 1.236, 0.516, 1.37, 1.094, 1.305, 1.2, 0.354, 0.932, 1.479, 1.311] limit 5.455 00051 num correct 42.0 weights [1.058, 0.966, 1.137, 1.044, 1.082, 0.876, 0.838, 1.578, 0.688, 0.711, 1.012, 0.919, 1.09] limit 5.786 00052 num correct 42.0 weights [1.361, 1.053, 1.308, 1.399, 0.139, 1.254, 1.702, 1.593, 1.603, 0.586, 0.568, 0.396, 0.037] limit 6.042 00053 num correct 42.0 weights [0.84, 0.964, 0.526, 1.111, 1.426, 1.096, 1.136, 1.328, 0.929, 0.85, 1.029, 0.489, 1.276] limit 4.969 00054 num correct 42.0 weights [0.912, 0.909, 1.165, 1.137, 1.382, 0.472, 1.562, 1.094, 0.81, 0.521, 1.228, 1.451, 0.358] limit 6.675 00055 num correct 42.0 weights [0.822, 1.167, 1.204, 1.129, 1.159, 0.744, 0.63, 0.857, 0.783, 0.978, 1.208, 1.145, 1.174] limit 5.149 00056 num correct 42.0 weights [0.722, 1.037, 0.781, 1.008, 1.098, 1.111, 1.038, 1.061, 1.019, 1.056, 1.109, 0.961, 0.999] limit 5.564 00057 00058 All 42 predictions were correct in both cases, even when we change the last prediction for 2024. 00059 00060 Remarks: 00061 00062 - The weights are normalized to be compatible with the original weights - 1.0 on average. 00063 00064 - The high variation of "fitting" weights shows that Lichtmanns weights and limit value are not special, 00065 many other weight sets work equally well - and could be justified for other reasons. 00066 00067 - If Lichtmanns weights would be "well balanced" you would expect an average weight value of 1.0 if you compute many solutions. 00068 But the first key usually gets a much higher weight as the fourth or the sixth one. Interestingly this holds only for the 00069 "Harris wins" prediction. 00070 00071 - If you collect a large number of solutions, the average value for a specific weight could indicate that this average used 00072 as weight could improve the reliability of future predictions. 00073 00074 - Nate Silver already said that "It’s less that he has discovered the right set of keys than that he’s a locksmith and can 00075 keep minting new keys until he happens to open all 38 doors". This example shows that you don't need to invent new keys 00076 to be a "locksmith" opening all doors, including future ones, predicting exactly what you want according to 00077 your political agenda. 00078 00079 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 00080 00081 Is there a way we can measure the "robustness" of a model? We could use an epsilon value defining a 00082 limit area [limit-eps, limit+eps] and could maximize this epsilon still maintaining all predictions correct. 00083 00084 Executing test_harris_prediciton_eps() we get: 00085 00086 Harris looses 00087 00088 num correct 42.0 eps 0.795 weights [2.498, 2.183, 2.07, 0.401, 2.42, 0.032, 0.807, 0.777, 0.136, 1.424, 0.118, 0.087, 0.047] limit 5.254 00089 num correct 42.0 eps 0.806 weights [2.866, 1.82, 2.559, 0.634, 2.667, 0.194, 0.766, 0.706, 0.006, 0.653, 0.025, 0.014, 0.089] limit 5.232 00090 num correct 42.0 eps 0.707 weights [2.128, 1.999, 2.034, 0.467, 1.967, 0.114, 0.928, 0.93, 0.344, 1.366, 0.023, 0.646, 0.054] limit 5.437 00091 num correct 42.0 eps 0.815 weights [2.918, 2.108, 2.256, 0.462, 2.344, 0.152, 0.515, 0.917, 0.109, 0.912, 0.092, 0.057, 0.157] limit 5.328 00092 num correct 42.0 eps 0.806 weights [2.573, 1.622, 2.445, 0.786, 2.038, 0.003, 0.74, 0.741, 0.451, 1.049, 0.345, 0.061, 0.147] limit 5.314 00093 num 0.018, 0.176, 0.02, 0.434] limit 5.39 00103 num correct 42.0 eps 1.466 weights [1.699, 3.483, 0.404, 0.755, 2.676, 0.727, 1.245, 0.951, 0.854, 0.11, 0.0, 0.036, 0.058] limit 5.4 00104 num correct 42.0 eps 1.311 weights [1.797, 2.869, 0.971, 0.907, 2.094, 0.815, 0.94, 0.936, 0.889, 0.007, 0.007, 0.768, 0.001] limit 5.943 00105 num correct 42.0 eps 1.399 weights [1.941, 3.16, 0.847, 0.873, 2.015, 1.095, 1.025, 1.018, 0.747, 0.002, 0.058, 0.21, 0.009] limit 5.683 00106 num correct 42.0 eps 1.406 weights [1.789, 3.271, 0.473, 0.914, 2.306, 0.671, 1.04, 0.868, 0.947, 0.223, 0.0, 0.014, 0.482] limit 5.17 00107 num correct 42.0 eps 1.407 weights [1.577, 3.531, 0.142, 0.769, 2.159, 0.984, 1.262, 0.806, 1.051, 0.06, 0.148, 0.102, 0.409] limit 5.337 00108 num correct 42.0 eps 1.385 weights [1.547, 3.297, 0.303, 0.747, 3.296, 0.512, 1.249, 0.8, 0.909, 0.154, 0.039, 0.105, 0.045] limit 5.135 00109 num correct 42.0 eps 1.347 weights [2.085, 2.899, 1.094, 0.87, 2.053, 0.834, 1.0, 0.938, 1.11, 0.095, 0.011, 0.007, 0.004] limit 5.439 00110 num correct 42.0 eps 1.349 weights [1.656, 3.134, 0.523, 0.873, 3.05, 0.607, 1.176, 0.876, 0.778, 0.041, 0.013, 0.084, 0.189] limit 5.173 00111 00112 Still all 42 predictions were correct in both cases, even when we change the last prediction for 2024. 00113 00114 Remarks: 00115 00116 - Now it becomes clear that some keys are almost irrelevant. 00117 00118 - Maximizing robustness - epsilon around the limit - leads to quite similar weight values in all optimization runs. 00119 00120 - The "Harris wins" prediction leads to a much larger epsilon value, so this prediction seems more robust. 00121 This result is consistent with Lichtmanns original prediction: Harris wins. 00122 In an earlier version of this example because of an error interpreting the prediction the result was different. 00123 00124 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 00125 00126 Finally lets maximize the limit area [limit-eps, limit+eps] for all old elections computing the optimal weights 00127 preserving all correct predictions. Then we compute the weighted sum for the 2024 election. 00128 00129 num correct 41.0 eps 1.381 weights [1.68, 3.213, 0.461, 0.803, 2.368, 0.804, 1.119, 0.864, 0.771, 0.076, 0.025, 0.731, 0.084] limit 5.822 00130 if sum is > 7.203 challenger wins, if sum is < 4.441 challenger looses 00131 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.948 00132 num correct 41.0 eps 1.325 weights [2.096, 2.997, 1.06, 0.844, 1.905, 1.221, 0.821, 1.108, 0.782, 0.0, 0.108, 0.052, 0.006] limit 5.575 00133 if sum is > 6.9 challenger wins, if sum is < 4.249 challenger looses 00134 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 3.207 00135 num correct 41.0 eps 1.387 weights [1.704, 3.399, 0.47, 0.875, 2.178, 1.329, 1.102, 1.018, 0.516, 0.127, 0.251, 0.016, 0.015] limit 5.551 00136 if sum is > 6.938 challenger wins, if sum is < 4.163 challenger looses 00137 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.317 00138 num correct 41.0 eps 1.348 weights [2.028, 3.18, 0.65, 0.97, 2.334, 0.73, 0.672, 1.112, 0.322, 0.037, 0.002, 0.01, 0.953] limit 5.19 00139 if sum is > 6.538 challenger wins, if sum is < 3.843 challenger looses 00140 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.725 00141 num correct 41.0 eps 1.376 weights [1.967, 2.796, 1.004, 1.042, 2.249, 0.663, 0.796, 1.041, 0.671, 0.002, 0.029, 0.0, 0.74] limit 5.213 00142 if sum is > 6.589 challenger wins, if sum is < 3.838 challenger looses 00143 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.973 00144 num correct 41.0 eps 1.355 weights [1.621, 3.287, 0.604, 0.676, 2.891, 1.056, 1.234, 1.058, 0.205, 0.223, 0.006, 0.089, 0.05] limit 5.369 00145 if sum is > 6.724 challenger wins, if sum is < 4.013 challenger looses 00146 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.536 00147 num correct 41.0 eps 1.379 weights [1.86, 2.816, 1.065, 1.107, 1.92, 0.985, 1.027, 1.032, 0.986, 0.013, 0.134, 0.048, 0.007] limit 5.557 00148 if sum is > 6.936 challenger wins, if sum is < 4.178 challenger looses 00149 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.985 00150 num correct 41.0 eps 1.431 weights [1.52, 3.65, 0.015, 0.765, 2.919, 0.782, 1.432, 0.773, 0.885, 0.157, 0.002, 0.001, 0.099] limit 5.166 00151 if sum is > 6.597 challenger wins, if sum is < 3.735 challenger looses 00152 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 1.693 00153 num correct 41.0 eps 1.394 weights [1.621, 3.375, 0.396, 0.871, 2.117, 0.833, 1.191, 0.851, 1.274, 0.019, 0.008, 0.01, 0.436] limit 5.197 00154 if sum is > 6.591 challenger wins, if sum is < 3.803 challenger looses 00155 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.045 00156 num correct 41.0 eps 1.378 weights [1.681, 3.251, 0.512, 0.951, 1.905, 1.064, 1.116, 0.776, 1.227, 0.109, 0.14, 0.016, 0.252] limit 5.319 00157 if sum is > 6.697 challenger wins, if sum is < 3.941 challenger looses 00158 2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = 2.318 00159 00160 So for all 10 runs the weighted sum is way below the threshold limit - eps, so we predict: Harris wins. 00161 ''' 00162 00163 import numpy as np 00164 import sys 00165 from fcmaes import retry 00166 from fcmaes.optimizer import Bite_cpp 00167 from scipy.optimize import Bounds 00168 from functools import partial 00169 00170 from loguru import logger 00171 logger.remove() 00172 logger.add(sys.stdout, format="{time:HH:mm:ss.SS} | {level} | {message}", level="INFO") 00173 00174 def r(v, n=3): return round(v,n) 00175 def rl(l, n=3): return str([r(v, n) for v in l]) 00176 00177 def is_false(s): 00178 if s.lower() == 'true': 00179 return 0 00180 elif s.lower() == 'false': 00181 return 1 00182 else: 00183 return None 00184 00185 def read_data(fname): 00186 00187 with open(fname) as f: 00188 lines = f.readlines() 00189 data = [] 00190 for line in lines: 00191 l = line.split() 00192 if len(l) < 2: 00193 continue 00194 if len(l) < 6: 00195 incumbant = l[-1] 00196 else: 00197 winner = l[-1] 00198 prop_vals = np.array([is_false(s) for s in l if not is_false(s) is None]) 00199 00200 #print(prop_vals, sum(prop_vals), incumbant == winner, (incumbant == winner) == (sum(prop_vals) > 5)) 00201 if (incumbant == winner) != (sum(prop_vals) > 5): 00202 print("exclude", prop_vals, sum(prop_vals), incumbant == winner, (incumbant == winner) == (sum(prop_vals) > 5), file=sys.stderr) 00203 else: # use only correct predictions: 00204 data.append((prop_vals, incumbant == winner)) 00205 return data 00206 00207 def collect_all_data(): 00208 data_old = read_data('data_old.txt') 00209 data_new = read_data('data_new.txt') 00210 data = data_old + data_new 00211 # check all predictions 00212 for props, inc_is_winner in data: 00213 if inc_is_winner != (sum(props) > 5): 00214 print("error, sum props", sum(props), "incumbant is winner", inc_is_winner, file=sys.stderr) 00215 return data 00216 00217 # optimize the correct predictions for a given model defined by its weights + limit 00218 def fit(n, props, inc_is_winner, x): 00219 weights = x[:-1] 00220 limit = x[-1] 00221 weights *= len(weights)/sum(weights) # normalize weights so that sum is num_props 00222 weighted_props = weights*props 00223 num_correct = sum( [ inc_is_winner[i] == (sum(weighted_props[i]) > limit) for i in range(n)] ) 00224 return -num_correct 00225 00226 # show 10 solution models for "Harris wins" and 10 for "Harris looses" 00227 def find_other_model(data, harris_predict = True): 00228 00229 props = np.array([d[0] for d in data]) 00230 inc_is_winner = np.array([d[1] for d in data]) 00231 # set for harris - last prediction 00232 inc_is_winner[-1] = harris_predict 00233 00234 n = len(data) 00235 num_props = 13 00236 dim = num_props + 1 00237 lb = [0.0]*dim 00238 ub = [1.0]*num_props + [13.0] 00239 bounds = Bounds(lb,ub) 00240 00241 for i in range(10): 00242 ret = retry.minimize(partial(fit, n, props, inc_is_winner), bounds, optimizer=Bite_cpp(1000), 00243 num_retries=32) 00244 weights = ret.x[:-1] 00245 limit = ret.x[-1] 00246 weights *= num_props/sum(weights) # normalize weights so that sum is num_props 00247 print ("num correct", -ret.fun, "weights", rl(list(weights)), "limit", r(limit)) 00248 00249 def test_harris_prediciton(): 00250 data = collect_all_data() 00251 print("Harris looses") 00252 find_other_model(data, harris_predict = True) # challenger (Trump) wins 00253 print("Harris wins") 00254 find_other_model(data, harris_predict = False) # challenger (Trump) looses 00255 00256 # optimize the correct predictions for a given model defined by its weights + limit 00257 # maximize an epsilon around the limit to improve robustness 00258 def fit_eps(n, props, inc_is_winner, x): 00259 weights = x[:-2] 00260 eps = x[-1] 00261 limit = x[-2] 00262 weights *= len(weights)/sum(weights) # normalize weights so that sum is num_props 00263 weighted_props = weights*props 00264 num_correct1 = sum( [ inc_is_winner[i] == (sum(weighted_props[i]) > limit + eps) for i in range(n)] ) 00265 num_correct2 = sum( [ (not inc_is_winner[i]) == (sum(weighted_props[i]) < limit - eps) for i in range(n)] ) 00266 return - (num_correct1 + num_correct2 + 0.1*eps) 00267 00268 # show 10 solution models for "Harris wins" and 10 for "Harris looses" thereby maximizing epsilon 00269 def find_other_model_eps(data, harris_predict = True): 00270 00271 props = np.array([d[0] for d in data]) 00272 inc_is_winner = np.array([d[1] for d in data]) 00273 # set for harris - last prediction 00274 inc_is_winner[-1] = harris_predict 00275 00276 n = len(data) 00277 num_props = 13 00278 dim = num_props + 2 00279 lb = [0.0]*dim 00280 ub = [1.0]*num_props + [13.0] + [4.999] 00281 bounds = Bounds(lb,ub) 00282 00283 for i in range(10): 00284 ret = retry.minimize(partial(fit_eps, n, props, inc_is_winner), bounds, optimizer=Bite_cpp(5000), 00285 num_retries=32) 00286 weights = ret.x[:-2] 00287 limit = ret.x[-2] 00288 eps = ret.x[-1] 00289 weights *= num_props/sum(weights) # normalize weights so that sum is num_props 00290 corr = int(-ret.fun) / 2 00291 print ("num correct", corr, "eps", r(eps), "weights", rl(list(weights)), "limit", r(limit)) 00292 00293 def test_harris_prediciton_eps(): 00294 data = collect_all_data() 00295 print("Harris looses") 00296 find_other_model_eps(data, harris_predict = True) # challenger (Trump) wins 00297 print("Harris wins") 00298 find_other_model_eps(data, harris_predict = False) # challenger (Trump) looses 00299 00300 def single_sum(n, single_props, weights): 00301 weights *= len(weights)/sum(weights) # normalize weights so that sum is num_props 00302 weighted_props = weights*single_props 00303 return np.sum(weighted_props) 00304 00305 def find_harris_estimate_eps(data): 00306 00307 harris_data = data[-1:] # harris props 00308 single_props = harris_data[0][0] 00309 00310 data = data[:-1] # remove harris result 00311 props = np.array([d[0] for d in data]) 00312 inc_is_winner = np.array([d[1] for d in data]) 00313 00314 n = len(data) 00315 num_props = 13 00316 dim = num_props + 2 00317 lb = [0.0]*dim 00318 ub = [1.0]*num_props + [13.0] + [4.999] 00319 bounds = Bounds(lb,ub) 00320 00321 for i in range(10): 00322 ret = retry.minimize(partial(fit_eps, n, props, inc_is_winner), bounds, optimizer=Bite_cpp(5000), 00323 num_retries=32) 00324 weights = ret.x[:-2] 00325 limit = ret.x[-2] 00326 eps = ret.x[-1] 00327 weights *= num_props/sum(weights) # normalize weights so that sum is num_props 00328 corr = int(-ret.fun) / 2 00329 print ("num correct", corr, "eps", r(eps), "weights", rl(list(weights)), "limit", r(limit)) 00330 print (f'if sum is > {r(limit+eps)} challenger wins, if sum is < {r(limit-eps)} challenger looses') 00331 # for i in range(len(data)): # uncomment to verify old predictions 00332 # print(f'election {i}, challenger wins = {inc_is_winner[i]}, sum = {r(single_sum(n, props[i], weights))}') 00333 print(f'2024 election, challenger wins = ?, sum = {r(single_sum(n, single_props, weights))}') 00334 00335 def test_harris_estimate_eps(): 00336 data = collect_all_data() 00337 print("without Harris election") 00338 find_harris_estimate_eps(data) 00339 00340 if __name__ == '__main__': 00341 test_harris_prediciton() 00342 test_harris_prediciton_eps() 00343 test_harris_estimate_eps() 00344 pass
